title: 112_s1324
content: The "Captive Primate Safety Act" adds nonhuman primates to the list of prohibited wildlife species under the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 are amended to include nonhuman primates as prohibited wildlife species. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 now prohibit the import, export, transport, sale, or purchase of live nonhuman primates in interstate or foreign commerce, with exceptions for veterinary care purposes. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 prohibit the transportation of live nonhuman primates unless certain conditions are met, including secure enclosure during transport, no contact with other animals or the public except for authorized personnel, and compliance with state and local laws. This does not apply to transportation to a designated caregiver. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 allow for the transportation of a nonhuman primate to a legally designated caregiver in the event of the previous owner's death, under certain conditions such as legal documentation, secure enclosure, no contact with other animals or the public, and compliance with state and local laws. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 permit the transport of a nonhuman primate to a designated caregiver after the owner's death, with conditions including legal compliance, secure enclosure, and adherence to state and local regulations. Nonhuman primates can also be transported for assisting individuals with severe mobility impairments, under specific criteria. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows nonprofit organizations with tax-exempt status to transport nonhuman primates to individuals with severe mobility impairments, under specific conditions. Nonprofit organizations with tax-exempt status can transport nonhuman primates to individuals with severe mobility impairments, under specific conditions including documentation from the organization and secure enclosure during transport. Nonprofit organizations can transport nonhuman primates to individuals with severe mobility impairments under specific conditions, including secure enclosure during transport and compliance with state and local regulations. In paragraph (3), certain animals listed in section 2(g) are replaced with prohibited wildlife species. In paragraph (3), animals listed in section 2(g) are replaced with prohibited wildlife species. Amendments to the Lacey Act include changing references from "animal" to "prohibited wildlife species" and updating time frames from 2004-2008 to 2011-2015. Civil penalties under the Act are also modified. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 are updated to include new criminal penalties and effective dates for regulations. The amendments involve inserting references to subsection (e) in various paragraphs and sentences. The Secretary of the Interior must create regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment to implement the amendments made in this section. Section 3 of the Captive Wildlife Safety Act is amended by removing subsection (b). The Secretary must create regulations to implement section 3(e) in consultation with relevant agencies.
